actions-list.actionItem: The House adjourned pursuant to a previous special order. The next meeting is scheduled for 2:00 p.m. on May 26, 2023.
On motion to adjourn Agreed to by voice vote.
Mr. Grothman moved that the House do now adjourn.
The House resumed Special Order speeches.
Pursuant to section 3(z) of H. Res. 5, the Chair announced the Speaker's designation of the period from Friday, May 26, 2023 through Sunday, June 4, 2023 as a "district work period."
The House has concluded all anticipated legislative business and has proceeded to Special Order speeches.
The House proceeded with further one minute speeches.
The House observed a moment of silence in remembrance of former Representative Tom Sawyer of Ohio.
Mr. Obernolte asked unanimous consent that when the House adjourns today, it adjourn to meet at 2:00 p.m. on May 26. Agreed to without objection.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On passage Passed by the Yeas and Nays: 289

actions-list.actionItem: The House adopted the amendments en gross as agreed to by the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
The House rose from the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union to report H.R. 467.

actions-list.header: On agreeing to the Pettersen amendment; Failed by recorded vote: 190

actions-list.actionItem: The House resolved into Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union for further consideration.
Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 467 — "To amend the Controlled Substances Act with respect to the scheduling of fentanyl-related substances, and for other purposes."
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of May 25.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess for a period of less than 15 minutes.
Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union rises leaving H.R. 467 as unfinished business.
On motion that the committee rise Agreed to by voice vote.
Mr. Bucshon moved that the committee rise.

At the conclusion of debate on the Pettersen amendment No. 3, the Chair put the question on adoption of the amendment and by voice vote, announced that the noes had prevailed. Mr. Pallone demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 429, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Pettersen amendment No. 3.

An amendment, offered by Ms. Pettersen,  numbered 3 to prevent H.R. 467 from taking effect until the Secretary of Health and Human Services and the Attorney General each certify that H.R. 467 will lead to a reduction in overdose deaths.
On agreeing to the Mills amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 429, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Mills amendment No. 2.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Mills,  numbered 2 printed in House Report 118-76 to add the Department of Defense as one of the agencies to be included in the research on fentanyl as a schedule 1 drug and require the OIG of the DOJ to complete and submit a study on its findings.
On agreeing to the Miller (OH) amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 429, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Miller (OH) amendment No. 1.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Miller (OH),  numbered 1 printed in House Report 118-76 to require the Attorney General to issue interim rules to implement this act 6 months after the date of enactment.
The House resolved into Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union for further consideration.
Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 467 — "To amend the Controlled Substances Act with respect to the scheduling of fentanyl-related substances, and for other purposes."
The House proceeded with one minute speeches, which by direction of the Chair, would be limited to 5 per side of the aisle.
The Chair designated Mr. Mast to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal.  Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by Dr. Michael T. Whitson, First Baptist Church Indian Trail, Indian Trail, North Carolina.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
